case_name: Union of India v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 536 of 1962 filed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 536 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 26, 1958, of Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 340 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 26. 1958, of the High Court at Patna in First Appeal No. 340 of .1951.

facts.text: Respondent sued Union of India representing G.I.P. Railway Bombay and E.I.R. Calcutta for recovery of damages for non-delivery of 31 bales of piece goods out of 60 bales consigned to Baidyanathdham from Wadibundar.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sued the Union of India as representing G.I.P. Railway, Bombay and E.I.R. Calcutta for recovery of damages for number-delivery of 31 bales of piece goods, out of 60 bales which had been companysigned to Baidyanathdham from Wadibundar.

facts.text: Consignment loaded in wagon No. 9643 on December 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This companysignment was loaded in wagon No. 9643 on December 1. 1947.

facts.text: Consignment reached Mughalsarai on the morning of December 9, 1947 by 192 Dn goods train.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the companysignment reached Mughalsarai on the morning of December 9, 1947 by 192 On goods train.

facts.text: Wagon kept in marshalling yard at Mughalsarai till December 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After reaching Mughalsarai, the wagon was kept in the marshaling yard till December 12, 1947.

facts.text: Wagon sent to Baidyanathdham by 214 Dn goods train from Mughalsarai at 6:40 p.m. on December 12, 1947 and reached on December 21, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It wag sent to Baidyanadham by 214 On goods train from Mughalsarai at 6- 40 p.m. on December 12, 1947 and eventually reached Baidyanathdham on December 21, 1947.

facts.text: Railway delivered 29 bales only to respondent on December 21, 1947; 31 bales missing.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who was the companysignee presented the railway receipt on the same day for delivery of the companysignment. Thereupon the railway delivered 29 bales only to the respondent and the remaining 31 bales were said to be missing and were never delivered.

facts.text: Notice given under s.80 CPC on August 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently on August 31. 1948, numberice was gyen under s. 80 of the Civil Procedure Code

facts.text: Suit filed on November 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and this was followed by the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen on November 20, 1948.

facts.text: Consignment booked under risk note form Z.

anchor.surface_text: The companysignment had been booked under risk numbere form Z which for all practical purposes is in the same terms as risk numbere form B.

facts.text: Railway claimed theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar on December 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the railway in this companynection was that there was a theft in the running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar on December 12, 1947 and that was how part of the company- signment was lost.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore dismissed the suit.

facts.text: High Court allowed the appeal and decreed the suit with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the High Court allowed the appeal and decreed the suit with companyts

facts.text: Notice under s.77 given on April 10, 1948 to Chief Commercial Manager, E.I.R.

anchor.surface_text: But we find in actual fact that a numberice was given by the respondent to the railway on April 10, 1948 to the Chief Commercial Manager, E.I.R.

facts.text: Wagon arrived intact at Mughalsarai on December 9, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute in this case that the wagon companytaining the companysignment arrived intact at Mughalsarai on December 9, 1947.

facts.text: Guard Ram Prasad Ram checked rivets and seals intact at Mughalsarai before departure on December 12, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that before the train started from Mughalsarai he patrolled both sides of it and the place from where the train started was well lighted and watch and ward staff also patrolled the area.

facts.text: Train stopped between Mughalsarai and Dildarnagar; northern flap door of wagon found open.

anchor.surface_text: His further evidence is that there were three escorts with the train and that they were guarding the train when the train was standing between the warner and the home signals before it reached Dildarnagar.

facts.text: At Dildarnagar, northern flap doors open, southern intact with original seals; wagon resealed.

anchor.surface_text: the evidence of Jagannath Prasad  P.W. 9  who was the Assistant Station Master at Dildarnagar that he found when the train arrived there that the numberthern flapdoors of the wagon were open while southern flapdoors were intact with the original seals.

facts.text: At Buxar, northern flap doors open; on checking December 14, 1947, 27 bales intact, one covering torn, one loose.

anchor.surface_text: Then the evidence of the Buxar station staff is that the numberthern flapdoors of this wagon were open when the train arrived at Buxar. It was then resealed and rivetted and was detached for checking. The checking took place on December 14th at Buxar.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored trial court decree.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore that of the Additional Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: No demand by respondent for disclosure before suit or during trial regarding watch and ward staff.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is numberproof that any disclosure was asked for in this behalf by the companysignor at any time before the, suit was filed.

facts.text: Loss due to theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar, no misconduct by railway servants.

anchor.surface_text: If the evidence of the guard is accepted, and we do accept it, there can be numberdoubt that the loss of the goods took place be-case of theft in the running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar.
Consequently on August 31. 1948, numberice was gyen under s. 80 of the Civil Procedure Code and this was followed by the suit out of which the present appeal has arisen on November 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Now s. 77 inter alia provides that a person shall number be entitled to companypensation for the loss, destruction or deterioration of animals or goods delivered to be carried by railway, unless his claim to companypensation has been preferred in writing by him or on his behalf to the railway administration within six months from the date of the delivery of the animals or goods for carriage by railway.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72  1  defines the responsibility of the railway administration for the loss, destruction or deterioration of animals or goods delivered to the administration to be carried by railway to be the same as that of a bailee under ss. 152 and 161 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, subject to other provisions of the Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Railway must disclose full handling of consignment in non-delivery cases before consignor proves misconduct

issues.text: whether non-delivery of goods carried by railway amounted to loss within the meaning of s. 77 requiring notice

anchor.surface_text: There was a conflict between the High Courts on the question whether non-delivery of goods carried by railway amounted to loss within the meaning of s. 77. Some High Courts including the Patna High Court held that a case of non-delivery was distinct from a case of loss and no notice under s. 77 was necessary in the case of non-delivery.

issues.text: whether the letter dated April 10, 1948 was sufficient notice under s. 77 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: But we find in actual fact that a notice was given by the respondent to the railway on April 10, 1948 to the Chief Commercial Manager, E.I.R. in which it was stated that 60 bales of cloth were booked for the respondent but only 29 bales had been delivered and the balance of 31 bales had not been delivered.

issues.text: the second question raised in the appeal: whether there was a breach of the condition of disclosure in risk note Z such that the risk note did not apply at all and liability assessed as simple bailee under s.72(1)

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second question raised in the appeal. We have already indicated that the High Court held that as the burden of disclosure which was on the railway had not been discharged there was a breach of one of the terms of the risk note Z and therefore the risk note did not apply at all

issues.text: the construction of the proviso to the risk note that arises in the present appeal

anchor.surface_text: But to this immunity there is a proviso and it is the construction of the proviso that arises in the present appeal. The proviso is in these terms-- Provided that in the following cases-- (a) Non-delivery of the whole of a consignment packed in accordance with

issues.text: whether misconduct on the part of the railway or its servants can be fairly inferred from the evidence produced by the railway

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the risk note would still apply and the court would have to decide whether misconduct on the part of the railway can be fairly inferred from the evidence produced by it. If the court cannot fairly infer misconduct from the evidence adduced by the railway,

arguments.claim: The suit was barred by s. 77 of the Indian Railways Act because notice required therein was not given by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It was first contended that the suit was barred by s. 77 of the Indian Railways Act, No. IX of 1890,  hereinafter referred to as the Act , inasmuch as notice required therein was not given by the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of one of the terms of the risk numbere Z and therefore the risk numbere did number apply at all and the responsibility of the railway had to be asse

arguments.court_reasoning: Non-delivery amounts to loss requiring notice per precedent; letter dated April 10, 1948 provided sufficient particulars per Jetmull precedent.

arguments.claim: Consignment sent under risk note form Z absolving railway from responsibility except upon proof of misconduct by respondent, who failed to discharge burden; disclosure made in written statement; loss due to theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar, no misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly it was contended that the consignment was sent under risk note form Z and under the terms of that risk note the railway was absolved from all responsibility for loss... The case of the railway in this connection was that there was a theft in the running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar on December 12, 1947

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ther. Section 72  1  defines the responsibility of the railway administration for the loss, destruction or deterioration of animals or goods delivered

arguments.court_reasoning: Risk note applies; no breach of disclosure; no misconduct inferred from evidence; burden not discharged.

arguments.claim: Non-delivery was due to misconduct of the servants of the railway.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed damages for non- delivery on the ground that the non-delivery was due to the misconduct of the servants of the railway, and the claim was for a sum of Rs. 36,461/12/-

arguments.court_reasoning: No misconduct proved or fairly inferred from railway evidence; respondent led no evidence.

arguments.claim: No notice under s.77 necessary in case of non-delivery, distinct from loss.

anchor.surface_text: On the first-point, the trial court held On the basis of certain decisions of the Patna High Court that no notice under s. 77 was necessary in a case of non-delivery which was held to be different from loss.

arguments.court_reasoning: Overruled by Governor-General v. Musaddilal; non-delivery is consequence of loss.

arguments.claim: Loss not due to misconduct of railway or servants.

anchor.surface_text: On the second point relating to the responsibility of the railway on the basis of risk note form Z, the trial court held that it had not been proved that the loss was due to misconduct of the railway or its servants.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; no fair inference of misconduct.

arguments.claim: Breach of condition of disclosure in risk note Z; risk note does not apply; liability as simple bailee under s.72(1).

anchor.surface_text: But on the second point the High Court was of opinion that there was a breach of the condition of disclosure provided in risk note Z under which the consignment had been booked, and therefore the appellant could not take advantage of the risk note at all

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gnment under from Z or form B is a specially reduced rate as companypared t3 the ordinary rate at which goods are carried by the railway and it is bec

arguments.court_reasoning: Breach does not void risk note; continues to apply, only facilitates inference of misconduct; no breach here anyway.

arguments.claim: Railway did not take proper care of wagon at Mughalsarai; seals/rivets broken there; theft by or in collusion with railway servants.

anchor.surface_text: and held on the evidence that the railway did not take proper care of the wagon at Mughalsarai and that in all probability the seals and rivets of the wagon had been allowed to be broken there and all arrangements had been completed

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at there was any breach by the railway of its responsibility to make full disclosure. In the circumstances we are of opinion that the risk numbere wou

arguments.court_reasoning: Guard's evidence accepted; wagon intact on departure; original seals found later; no demand for watch staff evidence.

arguments.claim: Non-delivery of goods amounts to loss within s.77 requiring notice.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruction, and therefore notice under s. 77 is necessary

arguments.claim: Letter dated April 10, 1948 is sufficient notice under s.77 even if not labelled as such.

anchor.surface_text: But we find in actual fact that a notice was given by the respondent to the railway on April 10, 1948... it gave all the particulars necessary in a notice under that section... Following that decision we hold that the letter in the present case... is sufficient notice

arguments.claim: Risk note form Z same terms as form B; Privy Council interpretation applies.

anchor.surface_text: With respect we are of opinion that this exposition of the law relating to risk note B applies also to risk note Z and we accept it as correct.

arguments.claim: Disclosure obligation under risk note proviso arises immediately on non-delivery but only if requested by consignor pre-suit; in suit, via court order after initial evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the responsibility of the railway administration to disclose... arises at once under the agreement... but we are not prepared to accept the contention... that this responsibility to make full disclosure arises immediately the claim is made... such disclosure is necessary only where the consignor specifically asks

arguments.claim: No breach of disclosure by railway as no pre-suit request or in-suit demand endorsed by court.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is no proof that any disclosure was asked for in this behalf by the consignor at any time before the suit was filed... Even after the suit was filed there was no statement by the respondent at any stage that the disclosure made by the appellant in the evidence was inadequate

arguments.claim: Breach of disclosure does not void risk note or revert to s.72(1) bailee liability; risk note continues, but misconduct more readily inferred, s.114 Evidence Act applicable.

anchor.surface_text: even if there is a breach of the term as to full disclosure it does not bring the contract to an end... The risk note would in our opinion continue to apply... where the railway has been in breach... misconduct may be more readily inferred and s. 114... more readily applied

arguments.claim: Guard's evidence credible; wagon intact with seals/rivets at departure from Mughalsarai; no tampering there.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that before the train started from Mughalsarai he patrolled both sides of it... rivets and seals of all the wagons... were checked... and there was apparently nothing wrong with them... On a careful consideration of the evidence of the guard we see no reason why his evidence should not be believed

arguments.claim: No adverse inference under s.114 Evidence Act for non-production of watch and ward staff or seal book as no demand made by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: But in the absence of any demand by the respondent for the production of the watch and ward staff... we see no reason why the statement of the guard... should not be accepted... It would have been a different matter if the respondent had asked for the production of the seal book

arguments.claim: Loss due to theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar; no misconduct by railway servants fairly inferred.

anchor.surface_text: If the evidence of the guard is accepted, and we do accept it, there can be no doubt that the loss of the goods took place because of theft in the running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar.

holdings.text: Failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruction, and therefore notice under s. 77 is necessary in the case of non-delivery which arises from the loss of goods.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held that failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Governor-General v. Musaddilal overruling Patna High Court view that non-delivery distinct from loss.

holdings.text: The letter dated April 10, 1948 is sufficient notice under s.77 even if not labelled as such, as it gave all particulars necessary.

anchor.surface_text: But we find in actual fact that a notice was given by the respondent to the railway on April 10, 1948 to the Chief Commercial Manager, E.I.R. in which it was stated that 60 bales

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provides all necessary particulars within time limit; following Jetmull Bhojraj precedent.

holdings.text: Risk note form Z is in the same terms as form B for practical purposes; Privy Council exposition in Surat Cotton applies equally to form Z.

anchor.surface_text: With respect we are of opinion that this exposition of the law relating to risk note B applies also to risk note Z and we accept it as correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Forms identical in relevant terms; direct analogy.

holdings.text: Breach of disclosure obligation under risk note proviso does not void the risk note or revert liability to s.72(1) bailee standard; risk note continues to apply, but misconduct more readily inferred via s.114 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: even if there is a breach of the term as to full disclosure it does not bring the contract to an end... The risk note would in our opinion continue to apply... misconduct may be more readily inferred

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods carried at reduced rate advantage already taken; follows Privy Council implication; harmonious construction prevents complete avoidance.

holdings.text: No breach of disclosure obligation by railway, as no pre-suit request by consignor and no in-suit demand endorsed by court after railway evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is no proof that any disclosure was asked for in this behalf by the consignor at any time before the suit was filed... Even after the suit was filed there

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disclosure required only on specific request pre-suit or court-endorsed demand post-evidence; none made here.

holdings.text: Misconduct on part of railway or servants cannot be fairly inferred from evidence produced by railway; burden shifts to consignor who led no evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the risk note would still apply and the court would have to decide whether misconduct on the part of the railway can be fairly inferred

holdings.reasoning_summary: Guard's evidence credible showing wagon intact on departure; no adverse inference without demand for further evidence like watch staff.

holdings.text: Loss occurred due to theft in running train between Mughalsarai and Buxar; no misconduct by railway servants.

anchor.surface_text: If the evidence of the guard is accepted, and we do accept it, there can be no doubt that the loss of the goods took place because of theft in the running train between Mughalsarai

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of guard, station staff at Dildarnagar/Buxar shows tampering post-departure; original seals later found.

holdings.text: Suit fails; appeal allowed, High Court judgment set aside, trial court decree restored.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and restore that of the Additional Subordinate Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts.

precedents.citation: Governor- General in Council v. Musaddilal  1

anchor.surface_text: Governor- General in Council v. Musaddilal  1  and the view taken by the Patna High Court has been overruled. This Court has held that failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruction, and therefore notice under s. 77 is necessary in the case of non-delivery which arises from the loss of goods. Therefore notice under s. 77 was necessary in the present case.

precedents.cited_proposition: failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and notice under s. 77 is necessary in case of non-delivery
precedents.cited_holding: failure to deliver goods is the consequence of loss or destruction and the cause of action for it is not distinct from the cause of action for loss or destruction

precedents.citation: Jetmull Bhojraj v. The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Jetmull Bhojraj v. The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway Co. Ltd. 2  and this Court held that .the letter to the railway in that case was sufficient notice for the .purpose of s. 77 of the Act. Following that decision we hold that the letter in the present case which is even more explicit is sufficient notice for the purpose of S 77 .of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Jetmull Bhojraj v. The Darjeeling Himalayan Railway Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: a letter giving particulars is sufficient notice under s. 77 even if not specifically stated as such
precedents.cited_holding: the letter to the railway in that case was sufficient notice for the purpose of s. 77 of the Act

precedents.citation: Surat Cotton Spinning Weaving Mills v. Secretary Of State for India in Council,

anchor.surface_text: Surat Cotton Spinning Weaving Mills v. Secretary Of State for India in Council,    and the law on the subject was laid down thus at pp.181-182 The first portion of the proviso provides that the Rail- Way Administration shall be bound to disclose to the consignor how the consignment was dealt with through- out the time it was in its possession or control, and, if necessary to give evidence thereof, before the consignor is called upon to prove misconduct.

precedents.case_name: Surat Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. v. Secretary of State for India
precedents.cited_proposition: obligation of disclosure under risk note arises upon non-delivery, extent of disclosure, procedure in court, effect of breach does not end risk note but allows inference of misconduct
precedents.cited_holding: the Railway Administration shall be bound to disclose how the consignment was dealt with; if breach, misconduct may be inferred using s.114 Evidence Act but risk note continues

anchor.surface_text: 1937 L.R. 64 I.A. 176. stage that the disclosure made by the appellant in the evidence was in any way inadequate. The respondent never told the court after the evidence of the railway was over that he was not satisfied with the disclosure and that the railway be asked to make further disclosure by producing such further evidence as the respondent wanted.

precedents.case_name: Surat Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills Ltd. v. Secretary of State for India
